factoid: Natásha thought of her brother when the congregation prayed for the warriors.
Natásha thought of Denísov when the congregation prayed for the warriors.
Natásha remembered Prince Andrew when the congregation prayed for all traveling by land and sea.
Natásha prayed for Prince Andrew when the congregation prayed for all traveling by land and sea.
Natásha asked God to forgive her all the wrongs she had done to Prince Andrew.
Natásha prayed for her father when the congregation prayed for those who love us.
Natásha prayed for her mother when the congregation prayed for those who love us.
Natásha prayed for Sónya when the congregation prayed for those who love us.
Natásha realized for the first time how wrongly she had acted toward her family when the congregation prayed for those who love us.
Natásha felt all the strength of her love for her family when the congregation prayed for those who love us.
Natásha tried to think of her enemies and people who hated her when the congregation prayed for those who hate us.
Natásha included the creditors among her enemies when the congregation prayed for those who hate us.
Natásha included all who had business dealings with her father among her enemies when the congregation prayed for those who hate us.
Natásha remembered Anatole when she thought of enemies and people who hated her.
Anatole had done Natásha so much harm.
Anatole did not hate Natásha.
Natásha gladly prayed for Anatole as for an enemy.
Only at prayer did Natásha feel able to think clearly and calmly of Prince Andrew.
Only at prayer did Natásha feel able to think clearly and calmly of Anatole.
For Prince Andrew and Anatole, Natásha's feelings were nothing compared with her awe and devotion to God.
Natásha bowed very low when the congregation prayed for the Imperial family and the Synod.
Natásha made the sign of the cross when the congregation prayed for the Imperial family and the Synod.
Natásha said to herself that even if she did not understand, she could not doubt.
Natásha loved the governing Synod.
Natásha prayed for the governing Synod.
The deacon crossed the stole over his breast after he finished the Litany.
The deacon said, “Let us commit ourselves and our whole lives to Christ the Lord!”
Natásha inwardly repeated, “Commit ourselves to God.”
Natásha thought, “Lord God, I submit myself to Thy will!”
Natásha prayed, “I want nothing, wish for nothing; teach me what to do and how to use my will! Take me, take me!”
Natásha had impatient emotion in her heart when Natásha prayed.
Natásha did not cross herself when Natásha prayed.
Natásha let her slender arms hang down while praying.
Natásha expected some invisible power to take her and deliver her from herself, from her regrets, desires, remorse, hopes, and sins.
The countess looked round several times at Natásha's daughter's softened face.
The countess looked round several times at Natásha's daughter's shining eyes.
The countess prayed God to help Natásha's daughter.
The deacon brought out a small stool in the middle of the service.
The stool was the one the deacon knelt on when praying on Trinity Sunday.
The deacon placed the stool before the doors of the sanctuary screen.
The priest came out with his purple velvet biretta on his head.
The priest adjusted his hair.
The priest knelt down with an effort.
Everybody followed the priest's example.
Everybody looked at one another in surprise.
The Synod prayed for the deliverance of Russia from hostile invasion.
The priest began the prayer with “Lord God of might, God of our salvation!”
The priest's voice was clear, not grandiloquent but mild.
The priest's voice is only used by Slav clergy.
The priest's voice acts so irresistibly on a Russian heart.
The priest prayed, “Look this day in mercy and blessing on God's humble people.”
The priest prayed, “Graciously hear us.”
The priest prayed, “Spare us.”
The priest prayed, “Have mercy upon us.”
The priest prayed, “This foe confounding God's land, desiring to lay waste the whole world, rises against us.”
The priest prayed, “These lawless men are gathered together to overthrow God's kingdom.”
The priest prayed, “These lawless men are gathered together to overthrow God's kingdom, to destroy God's dear Jerusalem, God's beloved Russia.”

The priest prayed, “These lawless men are gathered together to overthrow God's kingdom, to destroy God's dear Jerusalem, God's beloved Russia, to defile God's temples, to overthrow God's altars, and to desecrate our holy shrines.”
The priest asked how long, O Lord, how long shall the wicked triumph?
The priest asked how long, O Lord, how long shall the wicked wield unlawful power?
